module.title: Offensive Concepts
module.description: Master offensive formations, play types, and route concepts

lessons.title: Common Offensive Formations
lessons.description: Learn to identify the most popular offensive formations in football

variant.prompt_richtext: The quarterback is 5 yards behind the center with no running back beside him. What formation is this?
variant.explanation_richtext: Shotgun formation has the QB standing 5-7 yards behind center. This gives the QB more time to read the defense and is commonly used for passing plays.

variant.prompt_richtext: The QB is under center with a fullback and tailback lined up directly behind him in a straight line. What formation is this?
variant.explanation_richtext: The I-Formation gets its name because the QB, fullback, and tailback form the shape of an 'I'. It's a classic power running formation.

variant.prompt_richtext: The QB is in shotgun with the running back lined up beside him at about 4 yards deep. What formation is this?
variant.explanation_richtext: The Pistol formation combines elements of shotgun and under center. The QB is in shotgun but the RB is directly behind him, allowing for better running angles.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do teams use the shotgun formation?
variant.explanation_richtext: Shotgun gives the QB more time to scan the defense and throw. The QB doesn't need to drop back after the snap, making it ideal for passing situations.

variant.prompt_richtext: The offense has 4 or 5 wide receivers spread across the field with no running back. What formation is this?
variant.explanation_richtext: An Empty Set (or Empty Backfield) has no running backs, forcing the defense to cover more space. It's a pure passing formation.

variant.prompt_richtext: In a Singleback formation, how many running backs are in the backfield?
variant.explanation_richtext: Singleback has one running back in the backfield. It's a balanced formation that can run or pass effectively.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the main advantage of the I-Formation for running plays?
options_json: The fullback can lead block for the tailback
The QB has more time to throw
variant.explanation_richtext: In the I-Formation, the fullback leads through the hole and blocks defenders, creating a path for the tailback. This is classic power running football.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does 'under center' mean?
options_json: QB takes snap directly from center
variant.explanation_richtext: 'Under center' means the QB is directly behind the center and takes the snap by placing hands under the center's legs. This is the traditional QB position.

variant.prompt_richtext: In the Wildcat formation, who typically receives the snap?
variant.explanation_richtext: The Wildcat is a trick formation where a RB or WR takes the direct snap instead of the QB. It's designed to create confusion and running opportunities.

variant.prompt_richtext: The offense lines up with the QB under center and one RB offset to the left or right. What formation is this likely?
variant.explanation_richtext: This describes a Singleback formation with an offset back. The RB can go either direction, making it versatile for runs and passes.

lessons.title: Spread Formations
lessons.description: Understand spread offense concepts and receiver alignments

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the main goal of a spread formation?
options_json: Force the defense to cover more space
Pack more blockers near the line
variant.explanation_richtext: Spread formations spread receivers across the field, forcing defenders to cover more ground. This creates space for both passing and running plays.

variant.prompt_richtext: In a '4-wide' formation, how many wide receivers are on the field?
variant.explanation_richtext: 4-wide means four wide receivers are on the field, typically with one running back. This spreads the defense horizontally.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does 'Trips' mean in formation terminology?
variant.explanation_richtext: Trips (short for 'triple') means three receivers lined up on the same side of the field. This creates natural route combinations and overloads one side.

variant.prompt_richtext: In an empty backfield, where does the running back typically line up?
options_json: There is no RB on the field
variant.explanation_richtext: In empty formations, the RB usually splits out wide as a receiver, creating 5 eligible receivers. This is a pure passing formation.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'bunch' formation?
options_json: Multiple receivers lined up close together
variant.explanation_richtext: A bunch formation has 2-3 receivers lined up within a few yards of each other. This creates natural picks and makes it hard for defenders to cover man-to-man.

variant.prompt_richtext: How does spread offense help the running game?
options_json: Defenders must spread out, creating running lanes
variant.explanation_richtext: When defenders spread out to cover receivers, there are fewer defenders in the box. This creates more space for running backs to find holes.

variant.prompt_richtext: Where does a slot receiver line up?
options_json: Between the outside receiver and offensive line
variant.explanation_richtext: The slot receiver lines up in the 'slot' - the space between the outside WR and the offensive tackle. Slot receivers often run quick, precise routes.

variant.prompt_richtext: In a 5-wide formation, what is the biggest risk?
options_json: No blockers to protect the QB
variant.explanation_richtext: With 5 receivers, only the 5 offensive linemen are left to block. If the defense blitzes 6+ players, the QB will likely be under immediate pressure.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does '2x2' mean in formation terminology?
variant.explanation_richtext: 2x2 (or 'deuce') means two receivers on each side of the formation. It's a balanced spread look that doesn't tip off the play direction.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do spread offenses often use hurry-up/no-huddle?
variant.explanation_richtext: Hurry-up prevents the defense from substituting bigger/smaller players. If the offense has speed players, they can exploit mismatches before the defense adjusts.

lessons.title: Power Running Formations
lessons.description: Learn formations designed for physical, downhill running

variant.prompt_richtext: Which formation is best for short-yardage power running?
variant.explanation_richtext: The I-Formation is ideal for power running because the fullback can lead block and the tailback has a running start to hit the hole with momentum.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the primary job of a fullback in power formations?
options_json: Lead blocking for the running back
variant.explanation_richtext: The fullback is a blocking specialist who leads through the hole and blocks linebackers or safeties, clearing the path for the tailback.

variant.prompt_richtext: On the goal line, teams often bring in extra offensive linemen. What is this package called?
variant.explanation_richtext: Goal Line or Jumbo packages replace receivers with extra offensive linemen and tight ends. This creates maximum blocking power for short-yardage situations.

variant.prompt_richtext: What makes a formation 'strong' vs 'weak'?
options_json: The side with more blockers (usually the TE)
The side the QB looks at
The side with the best receiver
variant.explanation_richtext: The 'strong side' is the side with more blockers, typically where the tight end lines up. The 'weak side' has fewer blockers. This affects defensive alignment.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'Full House' backfield?
options_json: Three running backs behind the QB
variant.explanation_richtext: Full House has three backs in the backfield - typically a fullback and two halfbacks. It's an old-school power formation rarely seen in modern football.

variant.prompt_richtext: In power running formations, what is the tight end's primary role?
variant.explanation_richtext: In power formations, tight ends are extra blockers on the line of scrimmage. They block defensive ends and seal the edge for running plays.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is an advantage of using two running backs in the backfield?
variant.explanation_richtext: Two backs provide an extra blocker and create multiple run options. The defense doesn't know which back will get the ball or if one will block.

variant.prompt_richtext: In an offset I-formation, why is the tailback positioned slightly left or right?
options_json: To give a better angle to the intended hole
variant.explanation_richtext: Offsetting the tailback gives them a better running angle to the intended gap. It also helps disguise which direction the play is going.

variant.prompt_richtext: When would a team use a 'heavy' formation with multiple tight ends?
options_json: Short yardage or goal line situations
variant.explanation_richtext: Heavy formations with 2-3 tight ends are used when you need to gain just a few yards. The extra blockers overpower the defense in tight spaces.

variant.prompt_richtext: What's the main difference between power and finesse running?
options_json: Power uses blockers to create holes, finesse uses speed and misdirection
variant.explanation_richtext: Power running uses multiple blockers to physically move defenders and create holes. Finesse running uses speed, cuts, and misdirection to find openings.

lessons.title: Personnel Packages
lessons.description: Learn how teams use different player combinations

variant.prompt_richtext: What does '11 personnel' mean?
variant.explanation_richtext: Personnel packages use two digits: first is number of RBs, second is number of TEs. So '11' = 1 RB, 1 TE (and 3 WRs to make 5 skill players).

variant.prompt_richtext: In '12 personnel', how many tight ends are on the field?
variant.explanation_richtext: 12 personnel = 1 RB, 2 TEs (and 2 WRs). This is a balanced package that can run or pass effectively.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does '10 personnel' tell you about the formation?
variant.explanation_richtext: 10 personnel = 1 RB, 0 TEs, which means 4 WRs. This is a spread passing package with maximum receiving threats.

variant.prompt_richtext: When would a team use '21 personnel'?
variant.explanation_richtext: 21 personnel (2 RB, 1 TE) is versatile. The extra RB can block, run, or catch passes. It doesn't tip off run or pass.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is '13 personnel' best used for?
variant.explanation_richtext: 13 personnel (1 RB, 3 TEs) is a heavy package with lots of blockers. It's ideal for power running in short-yardage situations.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does '00 personnel' (or 'empty') mean?
variant.explanation_richtext: 00 or 'empty' personnel has no RBs or TEs - just 5 wide receivers. This is maximum spread for obvious passing situations.

variant.prompt_richtext: When the offense uses 11 personnel (3 WR), what does the defense typically do?
variant.explanation_richtext: Against 3+ WRs, defenses typically use nickel (5 DBs) to match speed. They replace a linebacker with an extra defensive back.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do offenses substitute personnel packages?
variant.explanation_richtext: Different personnel creates different matchups. For example, 4 WRs forces the defense to use smaller, faster players - which can help the running game.

variant.prompt_richtext: What type of plays is '22 personnel' (2 RB, 2 TE) typically used for?
variant.explanation_richtext: 22 personnel is a heavy, run-oriented package. With 2 RBs and 2 TEs, you have multiple blockers and power running options.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why might an offense hurry to the line after substituting personnel?
options_json: To prevent the defense from substituting
variant.explanation_richtext: If the offense substitutes and hurries to the line, the defense doesn't have time to substitute. This can create mismatches (e.g., LBs covering WRs).

lessons.title: Basic Route Concepts
lessons.description: Learn the fundamental passing routes receivers run

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'Go' or 'Fly' route?
variant.explanation_richtext: A Go route (also called Fly, Streak, or 9 route) is when the receiver runs straight downfield as fast as possible. It's used to attack deep coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: In a slant route, which direction does the receiver cut?
options_json: Diagonally toward the middle of the field
variant.explanation_richtext: A slant route has the receiver take 2-3 steps forward then cut sharply toward the middle. It's a quick, timing-based route.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is an 'Out' route?
options_json: Receiver runs downfield then cuts toward sideline
variant.explanation_richtext: An Out route (or Out-breaking route) has the receiver run 5-15 yards downfield then make a sharp 90-degree cut toward the sideline.

variant.prompt_richtext: In a curl route, what does the receiver do after running downfield?
variant.explanation_richtext: A curl (or comeback) route has the receiver run 10-15 yards downfield, then turn back toward the QB. It's effective against off coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'Post' route?
options_json: Receiver runs downfield then cuts toward the goal post
variant.explanation_richtext: A Post route has the receiver run 10-15 yards then cut at a 45-degree angle toward the middle (toward the goal post). It attacks deep middle coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: How does a corner route differ from a post route?
options_json: Cuts toward the corner of the end zone instead of middle
variant.explanation_richtext: A corner route cuts toward the corner of the end zone (outside) while a post cuts toward the middle. Both are deep routes but attack different areas.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'Hitch' or 'Stop' route?
variant.explanation_richtext: A hitch route is a quick route where the receiver runs 5-7 yards, plants, and turns back to the QB. It's used to get the ball out quickly.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'Drag' or 'In' route?
options_json: Receiver runs across the field horizontally
variant.explanation_richtext: A drag route has the receiver run parallel to the line of scrimmage across the middle of the field. It's effective against zone coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does 'route depth' refer to?
options_json: How many yards downfield the receiver runs
variant.explanation_richtext: Route depth is how far downfield the receiver runs before making their cut or catching the ball. Different routes have different depths.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'route tree'?
options_json: A numbered system for all possible routes
variant.explanation_richtext: The route tree is a numbering system (0-9) that represents different routes. For example, 9 is a Go route, 5 is an Out route. It helps QBs and receivers communicate.

lessons.title: Route Combinations
lessons.description: Learn how routes work together to attack defenses

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'route concept'?
options_json: Multiple routes designed to work together
variant.explanation_richtext: A route concept is a combination of routes designed to attack specific defensive coverages. Receivers run complementary routes that create natural throwing windows.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the 'Mesh' concept?
variant.explanation_richtext: Mesh has two receivers run crossing routes at the same depth, creating a natural 'pick' that makes man coverage difficult. It's very effective against man-to-man.

variant.prompt_richtext: In the 'Stick' concept, what routes are typically run?
options_json: Stick route, flat route, and vertical route
variant.explanation_richtext: Stick concept has a receiver run a 5-yard stick (hitch), a flat route underneath, and a vertical route to clear out. It creates a high-low read for the QB.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the 'Levels' or 'Hi-Lo' concept?
options_json: Routes at different depths to stress zone coverage
All routes at the same depth
variant.explanation_richtext: Levels has receivers run routes at different depths (high, medium, low) in the same area. This forces zone defenders to choose which level to cover.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'Flood' concept?
options_json: Three receivers attack one side at different depths
variant.explanation_richtext: Flood sends three receivers to one side at different depths (flat, intermediate, deep). It overloads zone coverage by putting more receivers than defenders.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the 'Smash' concept?
variant.explanation_richtext: Smash has an outside receiver run a corner route while an inside receiver runs a hitch underneath. It creates a high-low read against Cover 2.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do route concepts use different depths and spacing?
options_json: To create throwing windows and stress coverage
variant.explanation_richtext: Different depths and spacing force defenders to make choices. If they cover the deep route, the short route is open, and vice versa.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'Switch' or 'Rub' route?
options_json: Two receivers cross paths to create picks
variant.explanation_richtext: Switch routes have two receivers cross paths at different depths, creating natural 'picks' that make man coverage very difficult to execute.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'Four Verticals'?
variant.explanation_richtext: Four Verticals has four receivers run deep routes, stretching the defense vertically. It's designed to find holes in deep zone coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do offenses have multiple route concepts?
variant.explanation_richtext: Each route concept is designed to attack specific defensive coverages. Mesh beats man coverage, Levels beats zone, etc. Offenses need variety to adapt.
